TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit WSFederationHttpBinding extends System.ServiceModel.WSHttpBindingBase

Docs.summary: A secure and interoperable binding that supports federated security.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Federation is the ability to share identities across multiple systems for authentication and authorization. These identities can refer to users or to machines. Federated HTTP supports SOAP security as well as mixed-mode security, but it does not support exclusively using transport security. This binding provides Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) support for the WS-Federation protocol. Services configured with this binding must use the HTTP transport.
Bindings consist of a stack of binding elements. The stack of binding elements in <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSFederationHttpBinding> is the same as that contained in <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSHttpBinding> when <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSHttpBinding.Security%2A> is set to the default value of <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSFederationHttpSecurityMode.Message>.
The <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSFederationHttpBinding> controls the details of the message security settings, the values of which are available from the instance of <xref:System.ServiceModel.FederatedMessageSecurityOverHttp> that is returned by the <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSFederationHttpSecurity.Message%2A> property.
The <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSFederationHttpBinding> also provides a <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSFederationHttpBinding.PrivacyNoticeAt%2A> property to set and retrieve the URI at which the privacy notice is located.
> [!NOTE] > When calling a WCF service built with .NET Framework 4.0 or later from a WCF client application built with .NET Framework 3.5 or earlier, the configuration file generated by svcutil.exe or adding a service reference from Visual Studio contains the `establishSecurityContext` attribute in the binding configuration. This attribute is not recognized by the [!INCLUDE[netfx35_short](~/includes/netfx35-short-md.md)] runtime and the application throws an <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationErrorsException> with the message "Unrecognized attribute establishSecurityContext ". To workaround this problem, remove the `establishSecurityContext` attribute from the binding configuration.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The default value of <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSFederationHttpSecurityMode> is <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSFederationHttpSecurityMode.Message> which specifies that integrity, confidentiality, and server and client authentication are provided using SOAP message security. The details of these settings are available from the instance of <xref:System.ServiceModel.FederatedMessageSecurityOverHttp> that is returned by the <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSFederationHttpSecurity.Message%2A> property.

Public Overrides Function CreateBindingElements () As BindingElementCollection

Docs.summary: Creates a collection with the binding elements for the binding.
Docs.returns: The of type that makes up the binding.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The stack of binding elements depends on the value of the <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSFederationHttpSecurityMode> set.
The stack of binding elements in <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSFederationHttpBinding> is the same as that contained in <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSHttpBinding> when <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSHttpBinding.Security%2A> is set to the default value of <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSFederationHttpSecurityMode.Message>.
1. <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.TransactionFlowBindingElement>
2. <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.SymmetricSecurityBindingElement>
3. <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.TextMessageEncodingBindingElement>
4. <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.HttpTransportBindingElement>
However, setting <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSFederationHttpSecurityMode> to <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSFederationHttpSecurityMode.TransportWithMessageCredential> results in a stack that is something of a hybrid between the <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSHttpBinding> and <xref:System.ServiceModel.BasicHttpBinding> bindings.
1. <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.TransactionFlowBindingElement>
2. <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.TransportSecurityBindingElement>
3. <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.TextMessageEncodingBindingElement>
4. <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.HttpsTransportBindingElement>
Finally, using the MTOM encoder looks exactly the same as for <xref:System.ServiceModel.WSHttpBinding>.
1. <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.TransactionFlowBindingElement>
2. <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MtomMessageEncodingBindingElement>
3. <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.HttpTransportBindingElement>
